dt: {bc}to originate by a vital, chemical, or physical process {bc}{sx|produce||}
{bc}to be the cause of (a situation, action, or state of mind)

dt.t: these stories … {wi}generate{/wi} a good deal of psychological suspense

dt: {bc}to define or originate (something, such as a mathematical or linguistic set or structure) by the application of one or more rules or operations
{bc}to trace out (something, such as a curve) by a moving point or to trace out (a surface) by a moving curve

et: Latin {it}generatus{/it}, past participle of {it}generare{/it}, from {it}gener-, genus{/it} descent, birth {ma}{mat|kin|}{/ma}
shortdef: to bring into existence: such as
to originate by a vital, chemical, or physical process : produce

dt: {bc}to {d_link|generate|generate} (something, such as electricity or funds) by or for oneself

dt.t: … allowing the school the capability to {wi}self-generate{/wi} power until the power grid is restored.

Gregory Smith, associate dean for business and financial affairs for the Law Center, said the tuition increase is something the Law Center applied for through LSU out of a need to {wi}self-generate{/wi} revenue after state appropriations were cut by about 25 percent.
Just raising rates for those who cannot {wi}self-generate{/wi}, while those who can do so leave the grid, is not acceptable to us, as a matter of community well-being and fairness.

shortdef: to generate (something, such as electricity or funds) by or for oneself

dt: used to say that something or someone causes anger without making something (such as an issue under discussion) better understood

dt.t: Her inflammatory speech {phrase}generated/produced more heat than light{/phrase} on the topic.
The provocative new book {it}generates more heat than light{/it}.

shortdef: —used to say that something or someone causes anger without making something (such as an issue under discussion) better understood
